test_cases.output_expectation: A friendly greeting response acknowledging the question and providing a conversational reply.

test_cases.output_expectation: Hanoi is the capital of Vietnam.

test_cases.output_expectation: Detailed comparison highlighting key differences and similarities.

test_cases.output_expectation: Comprehensive essay-style response with multiple sections and detailed analysis.

test_cases.output_expectation: Technical explanation with relevant details and examples.

test_cases.output_expectation: Detailed comparison highlighting key differences and similarities.

test_cases.output_expectation: Comprehensive essay-style response with multiple sections and detailed analysis.

test_cases.output_expectation: Relevant response based on the input prompt.

test_cases.input_prompt:
translate this to vietnamese In 1989 Saigon had only one European restaurant, beef pho was a rarity and coffee a luxury. That was when Vietnamese-American Alain Tan Huynh returned to his homeland to open the first high-end restaurants in the city and with it a new chapter for its culinary and hospitality industry. Amid the patriotic fervor accompanying the 80th National Day celebrations, Huynh visited his son in Vietnam last month.
During his trip he stopped by Pho 2000 and two hotels on Le Thanh Ton Street.
Seated in the lobby of the Avanti Hotel and watching foreign tourists pass by, he seemed to relive memories of 36 years ago when Vietnam's tourism industry was still in its infancy and opportunities were limited.
In April 1989, as Vietnam entered the third year of its Doi Moi economic reforms, Huynh visited his homeland for the first time in nearly two decades.
The country was facing major challenges. The U.S. maintained its embargo, travel procedures were strict, the economy was plagued by shortages, and foreign investment laws were inadequate.
For overseas Vietnamese like Huynh, traveling home was especially difficult. Those holding U.S. passports could not obtain visas directly, and had to apply in Thailand.
Thailand benefited a lot from overseas Vietnamese returning to Vietnam at that time, Huynh recalls.
Most travelers stayed in Bangkok for two nights, spending money on food and lodging, while Vietnam was still struggling to take its first steps in tourism and services.
Overseas Vietnamese who wanted to visit home were required to come in controlled tour groups and seek permission for every place they wished to visit.
Arriving in Hanoi with a group of overseas Vietnamese, Huynh's first instinct was to find a bowl of pho.
But at that time few restaurants had beef pho on their menu since cattle was still used for draught work and rarely slaughtered, and they mainly served chicken pho.
Coffee was even harder to find, available mostly in hotels, while street vendors typically sold only iced tea.
What left the strongest impression on Huynh was not the food but the people.
At the Hoa Binh Hotel, when he ordered several dishes, the staff advised him to order a little at a time, finish everything, and then order more, otherwise it would go to waste.
When he tried to leave a tip, the staff returned it, saying he had forgotten his money.
He says: At that time I was very surprised, but I realized it reflected the sincerity of service workers, who did not put revenue first. It was a very Vietnamese kind of beauty.
The turning point in Huynh's career came on his second day in Hanoi when he was invited to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to meet Minister Nguyen Co Thach and Deputy Minister Vu Khoan.
The two welcomed him warmly, offering a cup of Thai Nguyen tea, local candies and candid conversation.
Thach told him: You are successful in the U.S., but Vietnam is still your homeland. The country is still poor and needs your contributions.
Noting his expertise in the restaurant industry and his experience in running a training school and restaurant chain in the U.S., he urged Huynh to help Vietnam train human resources to handle foreign visitors as the country opened its doors.
At the time the tourism industry was accustomed only to guests from the socialist bloc, and had little exposure to other sources of visitors even as preparations were underway for the 1991 National Tourism Year.
Huynh was invited by the General Department of Tourism to serve as a consultant and help set up Ho Chi Minh City's first joint venture restaurant.
International food was almost nonexistent in the city; there was just one European restaurant on Tran Hung Dao Street near today's Bui Vien area, a neighborhood then already popular with foreign travelers.
Although Huynh initially had no intention of investing, the invitation and love for his homeland persuaded him.
Three months after returning to the U.S. a burning desire to contribute caused him to come back to Vietnam.
He had had long discussions with his wife before they decided to make the move in December 1989, bringing their experience and training methods in restaurant and hotel services.

The department got him an old house on Ky Con Street to renovate into a restaurant.
But infrastructure was severely lacking as most old houses on the street were run-down and power outages occurred on four or five days a week.
Hearing the commitment from the tourism department that groups of tourists would be directed to the restaurant, I felt like an opportunity was arising before my eyes, Huynh says.
That same December Le Mekong restaurant opened, pioneering a new path for high-end cuisine in Ho Chi Minh City.
It had a bar on the ground floor, the restaurant on the first floor, a kitchen in the back, and a banquet room on the top floor.
In a room just 13 square meters on the rooftop, Huynh and his wife made their home.
They started out amid countless shortages.
Plates, spoons and forks had to be bought in Thailand; foreign wines and European ingredients were sourced wherever they could be found.
Without modern kitchen equipment, the couple improvised by building a charcoal grill, fanning flames while cooking at the same time.
Within a few months of opening Le Mekong ran up losses amounting to tens of thousands of dollars.
Despite the difficulties the couple did not give up.
In May 1990 Ho Chi Minh City began receiving a wave of foreign tourists, diplomats and investors, quickly turning the restaurant into the city's premier French dining destination.
The restaurant started making a profit.
Among its distinguished visitors was the late General Vo Nguyen Giap, who stopped by after a trip to India.
His visit boosted Le Mekong's reputation as a top high-end culinary address.
With Le Mekong's success, leading tour operator Saigontourist invited Huynh to establish Vietnam House on Dong Khoi–Mac Thi Buoi Street, serving authentic Vietnamese cuisine in an upscale setting.
Vietnam House became the first high-end Vietnamese restaurant in the city.
Its staff wore ao dai uniforms and there was live music on weekends.
The concept of the buffet ganh (buffet on trays) was introduced—staff sat in the dining room rolling spring rolls, making rice paper and presenting dishes on bamboo trays for guests to watch and enjoy.
The buffet ganh model was later widely adopted in many restaurants and hotels in Ho Chi Minh City Huynh says.
In 1995, after Vietnam normalized relations with the U.S., former President George Bush visited Ho Chi Minh City and stopped at Vietnam House to dine and host guests.
Building on these successes, Huynh took another bold turn by focusing on pho, a dish still considered everyday fare.
test_cases.output_expectation: Comprehensive essay-style response with multiple sections and detailed analysis.

test_cases.input_prompt: Solve the following complex math problem involving algebra and trigonometry: Let f(x) = 2x² + 3x - 7. If sin(θ) = 3/5 and cos(θ) = 4/5, calculate f(sin(θ)) + f(cos(θ)). Show all steps clearly, explain each substitution, and simplify the final expression. 🧮➗✖️
test_cases.output_expectation: Relevant response based on the input prompt.

test_cases.input_prompt: Balance the following chemical reaction: C₂H₆ + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O. After balancing, explain the principle of conservation of mass in detail, including why the number of atoms must remain the same on both sides. Also, describe how this reaction relates to combustion in real life (e.g., car engines). ⚛️🔥➕
test_cases.output_expectation: Relevant response based on the input prompt.

test_cases.input_prompt: A projectile is launched with an initial velocity of 20 m/s at an angle of 45° above the horizontal. 🌍🧲 Calculate (a) the maximum height reached, (b) the total time of flight, and (c) the horizontal range. Use g = 9.8 m/s². Show every formula (s = ut + 1/2 at², v = u + at, etc.), substitution, and step-by-step calculation. ⚡📐
test_cases.output_expectation: Relevant response based on the input prompt.

test_cases.input_prompt: Analyze the following quote from Shakespeare’s *Hamlet*: “To be, or not to be: that is the question.” 📜✒️ In your essay-style answer (minimum 300 words), explain its philosophical meaning about existence and suffering, compare it to modern existentialist thought (e.g., Sartre, Camus), and reflect on how this line might be interpreted differently in today’s society with the rise of mental health awareness. 💭🤯
test_cases.output_expectation: Relevant response based on the input prompt.

test_cases.input_prompt:
Find and correct all the grammatical and stylistic mistakes in the following long English passage (errors include subject-verb agreement, tense usage, punctuation, and awkward phrasing). Provide the corrected version and explain each change in detail: ✍️📝

"She don’t likes go to school everyday, because she feel tired and boring. The teacher, they was explaining the lesson but nobody were listening carefully. In the end of the class, he say everyone must to do the homework quickly otherwise you can’t pass. Their is many student which doesn’t understand the topic, but nobody ask question."

⚠️ Please rewrite it in proper academic English and then provide a bullet-point explanation for each correction. 📚🔍
test_cases.output_expectation: Relevant response based on the input prompt.

text_to_image.name: Text to Image

test_cases.input_prompt: Generate an ultra-detailed cinematic artwork of an endless desert landscape at sunset, golden sand dunes shimmering, abandoned ancient city half-buried in dunes, carved towers glowing faintly with celestial symbols, caravan of travelers on camels crossing the horizon, cinematic wide angle shot, atmospheric lighting. As the sun sets the sky transforms into galaxies and nebulas, hyper realistic stars filling the sky, narrow alleys illuminated with paper lanterns, exotic market stalls with spices, fabrics, glowing crystals, incense smoke filling the air. A palace made of obsidian and silver with crystal chandeliers, reflective marble floors, murals of gods and mythical wars, lush oasis gardens with waterfalls and cherry blossoms. Enchanted forest with glowing mushrooms, snowy mountains, stormy oceans with ships struck by lightning, floating steampunk cities with gears turning, surreal dreamscape where gravity breaks, rainbow fractals in the sky, time bending architecture, detailed shadows, volumetric lighting, cinematic realism, 8k render, ultra sharp textures. The description continues with layered sensory detail and symbolic imagery across natural, fantastical, and futuristic realms, designed as a stress test (~1000 words).
test_cases.output_expectation: output_images/t2i_013_generated.jpg

test_cases.input_prompt: Hãy tạo cho tôi một mô hình tượng mini biếm hoạ siêu thực, mô phỏng chân dung chính xác gương mặt của người trong ảnh. Nhân vật chính: Là chân dung siêu thực của người trong ảnh gốc, giữ đúng đường nét khuôn mặt, kiểu tóc, và biểu cảm nhẹ nhàng – tự nhiên – thân thiện. Thiết kế theo tỷ lệ đầu to – thân nhỏ (bobblehead style), phong cách như mô hình đồ chơi sưu tầm cao cấp. Trang phục thể hiện tinh thần dân tộc và ngày lễ 30/4: Nếu là nữ: mặc áo dài đỏ, ngực có ngôi sao vàng. Nếu là nam: mặc áo thun cờ đỏ sao vàng. Tay cầm lá cờ Việt Nam, giơ lên tự hào. Trên đầu có thể đeo băng đô “Tôi yêu Việt Nam” hoặc khăn rằn Nam Bộ, tăng không khí lễ hội. Bệ mô hình và bối cảnh phía sau: Nhân vật đứng trên nền mô hình thu nhỏ bản đồ Việt Nam, thiết kế nhiều tầng, màu sắc rực rỡ, sinh động. Phía sau là mô hình Dinh Độc Lập (TP.HCM) hoặc Lăng Bác với chi tiết kiến trúc đặc trưng: hàng cột, bậc tam cấp, cờ bay trên nóc, cây xanh và kênh nước mini.
test_cases.output_expectation: output_images/i2i_028_transformed.jpg

test_cases.input_prompt_1: European restaurant
test_cases.input_prompt_2:
In 1989 Saigon had only one European restaurant, beef pho was a rarity and coffee a luxury. That was when Vietnamese-American Alain Tan Huynh returned to his homeland to open the first high-end restaurants in the city and with it a new chapter for its culinary and hospitality industry. Amid the patriotic fervor accompanying the 80th National Day celebrations, Huynh visited his son in Vietnam last month.
During his trip he stopped by Pho 2000 and two hotels on Le Thanh Ton Street.
Seated in the lobby of the Avanti Hotel and watching foreign tourists pass by, he seemed to relive memories of 36 years ago when Vietnam's tourism industry was still in its infancy and opportunities were limited.
In April 1989, as Vietnam entered the third year of its Doi Moi economic reforms, Huynh visited his homeland for the first time in nearly two decades.
The country was facing major challenges. The U.S. maintained its embargo, travel procedures were strict, the economy was plagued by shortages, and foreign investment laws were inadequate.
For overseas Vietnamese like Huynh, traveling home was especially difficult. Those holding U.S. passports could not obtain visas directly, and had to apply in Thailand.
Thailand benefited a lot from overseas Vietnamese returning to Vietnam at that time, Huynh recalls.
Most travelers stayed in Bangkok for two nights, spending money on food and lodging, while Vietnam was still struggling to take its first steps in tourism and services.
Overseas Vietnamese who wanted to visit home were required to come in controlled tour groups and seek permission for every place they wished to visit.
Arriving in Hanoi with a group of overseas Vietnamese, Huynh's first instinct was to find a bowl of pho.
But at that time few restaurants had beef pho on their menu since cattle was still used for draught work and rarely slaughtered, and they mainly served chicken pho.
Coffee was even harder to find, available mostly in hotels, while street vendors typically sold only iced tea.
What left the strongest impression on Huynh was not the food but the people.
At the Hoa Binh Hotel, when he ordered several dishes, the staff advised him to order a little at a time, finish everything, and then order more, otherwise it would go to waste.
When he tried to leave a tip, the staff returned it, saying he had forgotten his money.
He says: At that time I was very surprised, but I realized it reflected the sincerity of service workers, who did not put revenue first. It was a very Vietnamese kind of beauty.
The turning point in Huynh's career came on his second day in Hanoi when he was invited to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to meet Minister Nguyen Co Thach and Deputy Minister Vu Khoan.
The two welcomed him warmly, offering a cup of Thai Nguyen tea, local candies and candid conversation.
Thach told him: You are successful in the U.S., but Vietnam is still your homeland. The country is still poor and needs your contributions.
Noting his expertise in the restaurant industry and his experience in running a training school and restaurant chain in the U.S., he urged Huynh to help Vietnam train human resources to handle foreign visitors as the country opened its doors.
At the time the tourism industry was accustomed only to guests from the socialist bloc, and had little exposure to other sources of visitors even as preparations were underway for the 1991 National Tourism Year.
Huynh was invited by the General Department of Tourism to serve as a consultant and help set up Ho Chi Minh City's first joint venture restaurant.
International food was almost nonexistent in the city; there was just one European restaurant on Tran Hung Dao Street near today's Bui Vien area, a neighborhood then already popular with foreign travelers.
Although Huynh initially had no intention of investing, the invitation and love for his homeland persuaded him.
Three months after returning to the U.S. a burning desire to contribute caused him to come back to Vietnam.
He had had long discussions with his wife before they decided to make the move in December 1989, bringing their experience and training methods in restaurant and hotel services.

The department got him an old house on Ky Con Street to renovate into a restaurant.
But infrastructure was severely lacking as most old houses on the street were run-down and power outages occurred on four or five days a week.
Hearing the commitment from the tourism department that groups of tourists would be directed to the restaurant, I felt like an opportunity was arising before my eyes, Huynh says.
That same December Le Mekong restaurant opened, pioneering a new path for high-end cuisine in Ho Chi Minh City.
It had a bar on the ground floor, the restaurant on the first floor, a kitchen in the back, and a banquet room on the top floor.
In a room just 13 square meters on the rooftop, Huynh and his wife made their home.
They started out amid countless shortages.
Plates, spoons and forks had to be bought in Thailand; foreign wines and European ingredients were sourced wherever they could be found.
Without modern kitchen equipment, the couple improvised by building a charcoal grill, fanning flames while cooking at the same time.
Within a few months of opening Le Mekong ran up losses amounting to tens of thousands of dollars.
Despite the difficulties the couple did not give up.
In May 1990 Ho Chi Minh City began receiving a wave of foreign tourists, diplomats and investors, quickly turning the restaurant into the city's premier French dining destination.
The restaurant started making a profit.
Among its distinguished visitors was the late General Vo Nguyen Giap, who stopped by after a trip to India.
His visit boosted Le Mekong's reputation as a top high-end culinary address.
With Le Mekong's success, leading tour operator Saigontourist invited Huynh to establish Vietnam House on Dong Khoi–Mac Thi Buoi Street, serving authentic Vietnamese cuisine in an upscale setting.
Vietnam House became the first high-end Vietnamese restaurant in the city.
Its staff wore ao dai uniforms and there was live music on weekends.
The concept of the buffet ganh (buffet on trays) was introduced—staff sat in the dining room rolling spring rolls, making rice paper and presenting dishes on bamboo trays for guests to watch and enjoy.
The buffet ganh model was later widely adopted in many restaurants and hotels in Ho Chi Minh City Huynh says.
In 1995, after Vietnam normalized relations with the U.S., former President George Bush visited Ho Chi Minh City and stopped at Vietnam House to dine and host guests.
Building on these successes, Huynh took another bold turn by focusing on pho, a dish still considered everyday fare.
test_cases.output_expectation: In-depth research report with multiple perspectives and detailed analysis.

Use academic style reasoning and include references to real-world projects like SpaceX, NASA Artemis, and international collaborations.
test_cases.output_expectation: In-depth research report with multiple perspectives and detailed analysis.

test_cases.input_prompt_1: Hãy tưởng tượng bạn đang viết một đoạn tường thuật về trận chiến Điện Biên Phủ năm 1954, mô tả diễn biến chính, các bên tham chiến và ý nghĩa lịch sử của chiến thắng này đối với tiến trình giải phóng dân tộc Việt Nam.
test_cases.input_prompt_2: Viết một phân tích thật chi tiết về tầm quan trọng của chiến thắng Điện Biên Phủ không chỉ trong lịch sử Việt Nam mà còn trên bình diện quốc tế. Hãy giải thích tại sao chiến thắng này được coi là bước ngoặt, kết thúc chế độ thực dân cũ và ảnh hưởng tới phong trào giải phóng dân tộc ở nhiều nước thuộc địa khác. Ngoài ra, hãy bổ sung góc nhìn về chiến lược quân sự, yếu tố địa hình, tinh thần chiến đấu và sự lãnh đạo chính trị đã góp phần làm nên thắng lợi này. Cuối cùng, hãy liên hệ tới các hệ quả sau đó như Hiệp định Genève 1954 và sự phân chia tạm thời đất nước, từ đó mở ra giai đoạn mới trong lịch sử.
test_cases.output_expectation: In-depth research report with multiple perspectives and detailed analysis.

test_cases.input_prompt_1: Trình bày nguyên lý cơ bản của thuyết tương đối hẹp của Albert Einstein, tập trung vào khái niệm tốc độ ánh sáng là hằng số và mối quan hệ giữa không gian – thời gian.
test_cases.input_prompt_2: Hãy viết một giải thích chi tiết, dễ hiểu nhưng đầy đủ về thuyết tương đối hẹp. Trước tiên, hãy mô tả bối cảnh khoa học đầu thế kỷ 20, những vấn đề trong cơ học Newton và lý thuyết điện từ Maxwell. Tiếp theo, giải thích hai tiên đề cơ bản mà Einstein đưa ra, làm rõ khái niệm tốc độ ánh sáng bất biến và tính tương đối của các định luật vật lý. Trình bày hệ quả nổi tiếng E=mc^2 và ý nghĩa của nó đối với vật lý hiện đại. Bên cạnh đó, hãy phân tích các hiện tượng cụ thể như giãn nở thời gian, co ngắn độ dài, và hệ quy chiếu quán tính. Cuối cùng, hãy thảo luận tác động của lý thuyết này đến công nghệ hiện đại (ví dụ GPS, năng lượng hạt nhân) và triết học về không gian – thời gian.
test_cases.output_expectation: In-depth research report with multiple perspectives and detailed analysis.

test_cases.output_expectation: Current, up-to-date information relevant to the search query.

test_cases.input_prompt: Cập nhật chi tiết nhất về trận chung kết bóng đá nam Olympic 2025 giữa Brazil và Argentina. Hãy cung cấp tỷ số trực tiếp, thống kê kiểm soát bóng, số lần sút, số cú sút trúng đích, thẻ vàng, thẻ đỏ, số pha phạm lỗi, số lần đá phạt góc. Ngoài ra, cần bổ sung mô tả tình huống ghi bàn từng phút, phản ứng của cầu thủ, huấn luyện viên, khán giả trên sân vận động và người hâm mộ trên mạng xã hội trong 5 phút qua. Đồng thời, hãy so sánh phong độ của hai đội trong suốt giải đấu, liệt kê các cầu thủ ghi bàn nhiều nhất, thủ môn cứu thua nhiều nhất và nhận định của chuyên gia về chiến thuật hai đội đang áp dụng. Cuối cùng, bổ sung dự đoán hiệp phụ hoặc loạt sút luân lưu nếu trận đấu kết thúc hòa trong 90 phút chính thức.
test_cases.output_expectation: Current, up-to-date information relevant to the search query.
